introduction.p: So far, we have focused our attention on a small collection of basic functions functions \frac{1}{1-x}, \ln(1+x), \sin(x), \cos(x), and e^x and their Taylor series centered at a = 0. One of the reasons we were able to find these Taylor series is that clear patterns arise in the derivatives of each of these functions. While we can always use Definition to find the first few terms of a Taylor series, finding a pattern among the various derivatives is challenging for most functions. In Preview Activity, we explore this issue and investigate a different approach to finding the Taylor series of the function.

subsection.title: Using substitution and algebra to find new Taylor series expressions
subsection.p:
The substitution technique we used in Preview Activity can be used to find the Taylor series for any function whose structure is similar to that of a Taylor series we already know. For instance, since
f(x) = \cos(x) = 1 - \frac{1}{2!}x^2 + \frac{1}{4!}x^4 - \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n)!} x^{2n} + \cdots
for all x, we can change variables and view this equation as saying
f(u) = \cos(u) = 1 - \frac{1}{2!}u^2 + \frac{1}{4!}u^4 - \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n)!} u^{2n} + \cdots
for all u. If we then wanted to find the Taylor series expansion for g(x) = x^4 \cdot \cos(x^3), we could do so using the following process.

First, by letting u = x^3, we see that Equation implies
\cos(x^3) = 1 - \frac{1}{2!}(x^3)^2 + \frac{1}{4!}(x^3)^4 - \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n)!} (x^3)^{2n} + \cdots , or
\cos(x^3) = 1 - \frac{1}{2!}x^6 + \frac{1}{4!}x^{12} - \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n)!} x^{6n} + \cdots . Then, multiplying both sides of Equation by x^4, we find that
g(x) = x^4 \cos(x^3) = x^4 - \frac{1}{2!}x^{10} + \frac{1}{4!}x^{16} - \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n)!} x^{6n+4} + \cdots . Since Equation is valid for every real number u, letting u = x^3 tells us that Equation is valid for every real number x. The Ratio Test can be used to show that multiplying every term of a Taylor series by the same power of x does not change the set of x-values for which the series converges, so the Taylor series for g(x) also converges for every value of x.
In Activity, we find several Taylor series using similar techniques to our approach for x^4 \cos(x^3) above.

subsection.title: Differentiating and integrating Taylor series
subsection.p:
In Section, we discussed the challenge posed by the definite integral
\int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx . Because we are unable to find a simple algebraic antiderivative for the function e^{-x^2}, we cannot use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus to evaluate the integral exactly. An alternate approach is to estimate the integral using an effective numerical approximation technique such as Simpson's Rule.

Our recent work with Taylor series now suggests another way to evaluate \int_0^1 e^{-x^2} \, dx, and this approach also provides new options for finding additional Taylor series. In Activity, we found that
e^{-x^2} = 1 - x^2 + \frac{1}{2!}x^4 - \frac{1}{3!}x^6 + \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{n!} x^{2n} + \cdots
and that this representation of e^{-x^2} is valid for every value of x. This infinite series representation naturally suggests that we could find an antiderivative of e^{-x^2} by integrating both sides of Equation. Doing so, we see
\int e^{-x^2} \, dx =\mathstrut \amp \int \left( 1 - x^2 + \frac{1}{2!}x^4 - \frac{1}{3!}x^6 + \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{n!} x^{2n} + \cdots \right) \, dx =\mathstrut \amp C + x - \frac{1}{3}x^3 + \frac{1}{5 \cdot 2!} x^5 - \frac{1}{7 \cdot 3!}x^7 + \cdots + (-1)^n \frac{1}{(2n+1) \cdot n!} x^{2n+1} + \cdots

It is not immediately apparent how integrating a Taylor series might change the values of x for which the series converges. It turns out that both differentiating and integrating a power series has almost no effectIt is possible for the convergence status at the endpoints of the interval to change, but we are normally not concerned with those specific x-values. on where the series converges, as stated in a result from advanced calculus, The Power Series Differentiation and Integration Theorem.
